title: Has there historically ever been a presidential political debate where both candidates almost completely agreed with one another? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: I did a little research, and I could not find one instance of a political debate where the candidates for office agreed on every point, or “…almost completely agreed with one another?” Political debates in the 19th century were generally much longer than modern debates. Generally each participant, as in the Lincoln-Douglas debates, spoke for one hour without interruption. Then the other candidate spoke for one hour. Then there was a half hour for each to give rebuttal of the other. It wouldn’t be a debate, as another answer to this question indicated, if each candidate agreed in whole or substance with the other. Up until the first televised debate between John Kennedy and Richard Nixon, the most famous debates were the Lincoln-Douglas debates of the 1858. Lincoln (left side) and Douglas (right side)

I doubt it; there probably were some debates where both candidates agreed on 1 or 2 points, but actually the purpose of political debates is to highlight the disagreement between the political parties policies, platforms, & strategies.
While I have never researched historical debates, I can’t think of any two candidates whose party affiliation aligned enough that there would be agreement on more than a point or two.
Hi, it would not be much of a debate if they agreed. The debates are not about issues and information, it’s about getting vote at the election and style is what matters.
